item.title: "Portrait and Text: African American Artists of Dance, Music, and the Written Word"
item.description:
Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library
10th floor, Woodruff Library
Ongoing through Thursday, December 22, 2011

Extended through December 2011! Featuring portraits by Harlem arts patron and photographer Carl Van Vechten and MARBL’s exceptional collection of African American primary sources, this exhibition offers a unique perspective on many renowned African American writers, actors, singers, and dancers. Included are Langston Hughes, Zora Neale Hurston, Harry Belafonte, Richard Wright, Marian Anderson, Carmen de Lavallade, Pearl Primus, Countee Cullen, Josephine Baker, Paul Robeson, and many others.

The exhibition is co-curated by Kelly Erby, now teaching at Georgia State University and a recent Emory PhD, and Randall K. Burkett, Curator of African American Collections at Emory.

item.title: Divine Intervention: African Art and Religion
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Ongoing through Sunday, December 4, 2011



This exhibition illustrates the traditional African belief that works of art function as a bridge between the human and divine worlds. Through its creation or through its use in ritual, a work of art becomes potent, filled with the power of the spirit and ancestral realms, and can effect change and transformation in the lives of human beings. The exhibition features over 50 works from over twenty African cultures including familiar items such as masks and shrines, and less familiar items like the jacket of a hunter from Mali. Covered with amulets, mirrors, talons, and other objects believed to be imbued with nyama, or ritual potency, the jacket both empowers and protects the hunter. Also included are divining instruments that facilitate human communication with ancestors and other spirits. The works in Divine Intervention illustrate the active nature of African art, in which works of art are not passive representations of deities, ancestors, or spirits, but rather agents of communication between the divine and earthly realms.

item.title: “Shadows of the Sun: The Crosbys, the Black Sun Press & the Lost Generation”
item.description:
Schatten Gallery, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Ongoing through Friday, March 16, 2012

An exhibition that shines a light on the press, modernism, and the generation of writers, artists, jazz musicians, and exiles in Paris after the First World War. The Black Sun Press, founded by Caresse and Harry Crosby in Paris in the 1920s, is emblematic of the avant-garde nature and adventurous spirit of the Lost Generation during that time. Curated by Kevin Young. Opening reception: Tues. Sept. 27 5:30-7:30 pm, Schatten Gallery. A small, accompanying exhibition called “Postcards from Paris” about expatriate literary and artistic figures is curated by Amy Hildreth, a doctoral candidate in English. Check library hours first at web.library.emory.edu…. More info: web.library.emory.edu…

item.title: Life and Death in the Pyramid Age: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Ongoing through Sunday, December 11, 2011

Acquired from excavations at the sacred site of Abydos in Middle Egypt by Emory Theology Professor, Rev. William A. Shelton in 1920, the Emory Old Kingdom mummy is the oldest Egyptian mummy in the Western Hemisphere and one of no more than half a dozen known to exist in the world.

Current examinations being undertaken at Emory Hospital and in the Carlos Museum’s conservation lab promise to reveal much about the little understood origins of mummification in Egypt. No other mummy of this early date has been investigated using modern scientific procedures such as CT-scanning, radiocarbon dating, blood typing, and spectroscopic analysis.

The exhibition will also place the mummy within the context of ancient Egypt's practice of mummification, burial, and the cult of the dead, as well as exploring the social and political changes that marked the end of the Pyramid Age. The development of the site of Abydos and the cult of Osiris will also be a focus of the exhibition, with a link to the current excavations at the Middle Cemetery where the Old Kingdom mummy was found nearly a century ago.

Newly conserved for this exhibition, the mummy will be shown for the first time in more than a generation and due to its fragility, it will only be seen at the Carlos Museum.

item.title: “The Portrait Project: A Snapshot of Emory Libraries Staff,” featuring the work of Melanie Bunn
item.description:
Level 2, Woodruff Library
Ongoing through Friday, January 13, 2012

This exhibition features 20 portraits of library colleagues painted by stacks and storage supervisor Melanie Bunn. Each portrait is accompanied by a caption describing the person’s role in the library with the intention of raising the visibility of the often-anonymous work done by library staff across multiple units.

item.title: John W. Ford: House Not a Home
item.description:
Visual Arts Gallery
700 Peavine Creek Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Ongoing through Saturday, October 22, 2011

Closing Reception: Thursday, October 20, 5–8 pm; Gallery Talk by John W. Ford, 6:30 pm
*******
John W. Ford is interested in objects, memory and space--both physical and metaphysical. He works in a wide variety of materials, from multimedia sculptures to installation to graphic arts.

“I am interested in the power of small objects and collections of small objects to catalyze interpretation and speculative meaning,” Ford explains.

Ford’s work has been shown in Ireland, Russia, Poland, Mexico, Canada and throughout the United States. He has been the recipient of numerous grants and awards including a Pollock Krasner Artist Grant, North Carolina Arts Council Artist Fellowship, Virginia A. Groot Foundation Grant, Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Grant, and an ArtsLink Project Grant.

item.title: "The Abandoned Mansion"
item.description:
Woodruff Library, ECIT Gallery Level 2
Ongoing through Friday, January 6, 2012

An exhibition of images from Atlanta-based photographer Brian McGrath Davis, PhD candidate at Emory’s ILA. In previous lives, the mansion on Emory’s Briarcliff campus was a mental health institution and an outpatient addiction recovery center, but first it was the 1920s estate of Asa Candler Jr., son of the founder of The Coca-Cola Company. Boarded up since the late ’90s, the abandoned mansion continues to be a source of fascination, and Davis was granted access for this project.

item.title: Watching Hands: Artists Respond to Keeping Well
item.description:
David J. Sencer CDC Museum
1600 Clifton Rd.
Atlanta, GA 30333
Ongoing through Friday, January 13, 2012

Watching Hands: Artists Respond to Keeping Well showcases the work of six artists who interpret the act of hand washing in innovative and unexpected ways. Recent H1N1 prevention campaigns have highlighted the importance of hand washing as one of the most effective ways to stay well. Sponsored by Georgia Pacific and the CDC Foundation, and curated by Louise E. Shaw, CDC Museum Curator, this exhibition will stretch the boundaries of current public health campaigns through painting, drawing, graphic design, sculpture, installation, and new media. Making the connection between hand washing and keeping well, the work—all new for this exhibition--ranges from the humorous to the spiritual. The artists include: John Bankston (San Francisco); Didi Dunphy (Athens, GA); Joe Peragine (Atlanta); Katherine L. Ross (Chicago); Laura Splan (Brooklyn, NY); and James Victore (Brooklyn, NY).

item.title: A Harlot's Progress: Hogarth's Comic History
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Ongoing through Sunday, December 4, 2011

The John Howett Works on Paper Gallery will feature the complete series of William Hogarth’s "A Harlot’s Progress" from the Museum’s permanent collections. The engravings, originally published in 1732, were the first of several satirical series by the British painter and printmaker that he referred to as “modern moral subjects.” The story of the Harlot illustrates the downfall of a fictional young woman in a corrupt eighteenth-century London.

Sold by subscription, the series was so popular that it was widely copied by other engravers and published in various editions. This led Hogarth to join with other artists to successfully lobby Parliament to enact a law protecting the copyright of engravers.

In six scenes Hogarth illustrates the girl’s “progress” from glowing innocence through criminality and imprisonment to disease and death. The title is an ironic reference to John Bunyan’s allegory of salvation Pilgrim’s Progress. There are sly allusions both literary and topical throughout the series, including a cameo appearance by Captain MacHeath, the original Mack the Knife. Hogarth includes several actual notorious characters of the day and bases the outlines of the story on real events reported in periodicals like The Spectator. Steeped in the atmosphere of contemporary London, Hogarth’s story is presented with a fresh directness and a biting wit.

Several educational programs will accompany the exhibition. These include a lecture by Martine Brownley, Goodrich C. White Professor of English at Emory University, on November 10, titled The World of Hogarth, and a young adult printmaking workshop, The Art of the Print and Social Commentary, on November 6.

item.title: The Mind's Eye - A Photo Exhibit by Myron McGhee
item.description:
Center for Ethics
1531 Dickey Drive
Atlanta, GA 30322
Ongoing through Monday, October 31, 2011

The Mind's Eye is an exhibit of Myron McGhee's photographs of Tibetan monks painting sand mandalas at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia.

While the monks focus their attention on the artistic elements of creating the sand mandala, they also devote their minds to meditation for the healing of the earth. Observing their sacred practice, our eyes are drawn to the exquisite beauty of their art, and our minds are inspired by their religious devotion.

This collection of photographs will be on exhibit at various venues on Emory's campus throughout the 2011-2012 academic year. The exhibit is curated by Juana Clem McGhee and made possible through generous support from the university and other organizations in the Atlanta area.

To view exhibits online, go to www.myron.smugmug.com…

item.title: Water Study: A Site-Specific Event
item.description:
Baker Woodlands/Source Route sculpture
Sunday, October 16, 2011, 6 p.m.

Water Study is a site-specific collaborative work created by D. Patton White, Emory dance alumnus and artistic director of Beacon Dance. The work features Emory students and members of Beacon Dance. Structured as a tour of a scientific experiment, Water Study will take the audience on a journey through the environment of the Baker Woodlands ravine where they will encounter not only the scientists, but the subjects of the experiment. What will happen when the subjects begin to respond in completely unanticipated ways?

PLEASE NOTE: The Arts at Emory Box Office is closed on the weekends. Calls made on Saturday October 15th, or Sunday October 16th for weekend reservations, should be directed to Beacon Dance at 404.377.2929.

Please note: The audience will travel on terrain of varying difficulty. Warm comfortable clothing, hiking shoes, and insect repellant are recommended. Flashlights will be provided to the audience members. Performances will take place rain or shine; please dress accordingly and bring your own umbrella.

This project is sponsored in part by a grant from the Emory College Center for Creativity and Arts.

Performances:
Sat., Oct. 15, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Sun., Oct. 16, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Mon., Oct. 17, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Tues., Oct. 18, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Wed., Oct. 19, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.

item.description:
Baker Woodlands/Source Route sculpture
Sunday, October 16, 2011, 8 p.m.

Water Study is a site-specific collaborative work created by D. Patton White, Emory dance alumnus and artistic director of Beacon Dance. The work features Emory students and members of Beacon Dance. Structured as a tour of a scientific experiment, Water Study will take the audience on a journey through the environment of the Baker Woodlands ravine where they will encounter not only the scientists, but the subjects of the experiment. What will happen when the subjects begin to respond in completely unanticipated ways?

PLEASE NOTE: The Arts at Emory Box Office is closed on the weekends. Calls made on Saturday October 15th, or Sunday October 16th for weekend reservations, should be directed to Beacon Dance at 404.377.2929.

Please note: The audience will travel on terrain of varying difficulty. Warm comfortable clothing, hiking shoes, and insect repellant are recommended. Flashlights will be provided to the audience members. Performances will take place rain or shine; please dress accordingly and bring your own umbrella.

This project is sponsored in part by a grant from the Emory College Center for Creativity and Arts.

Performances:
Sat., Oct. 15, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Sun., Oct. 16, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Mon., Oct. 17, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Tues., Oct. 18, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Wed., Oct. 19, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.

item.title: RATHSKELLAR EATS A VERMONSTER
item.description:
Harland Cinema
3rd Floor of the Dobbs University Center
605 Asbury Circle
Atlanta, Georgia 30322
Sunday, October 16, 2011, 8 – 9 p.m.

Join Rathskellar for their first full improv show of the year! This time, we're kicking it off big with a challenge - the VERMONSTER CHALLENGE. We will be eating a bucket of Ben & Jerry's ice cream, with all the fixin's, during the show. It will be messy, and it will be sugar-hyper.
Your mission - Sunday, October 16th, 8 p.m., Harland Cinema: see some improv comedy, and support us in the valiant battle against the VERMONSTER.

As always, it's FREE to all!

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, October 17, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Robert Graves’ two novels, "I Claudius" and "Claudius the God" paint a compelling portrait of Rome’s first imperial dynasty, the Julio-Claudians. Meticulously based on ancient authors such as Tacitus and Suetonius, the novels reveal Graves’ expert training in Classics at Oxford. But how accurate is Graves’s depiction? Dr. Eric Varner, Associate Professor of Art History and Classics, will lead readers in an investigation not just of the novels themselves, but of what art historical and archaeological evidence might also reveal about the hidden lives of Rome’s First Family. Fee, which includes the cost of both books: $50 for Museum members; $75 for non-members.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

item.title: Vessel—A Water Happening
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, October 18, 2011, 12 p.m.

Be part of a movement ritual that connects you to water. Anyone can participate. This "happening" begins in the Michael C. Carlos Museum rotunda, finding its flow within the vessels of antiquity; vessels that would have stored water for a family in seventh century BC. The act of pouring the water from one vessel to another will continue, extending and wrapping around campus, until the water is depleted. Lori Teague, Emory dance faculty, will facilitate the structured improvisation, framing our intention. Vessels will be provided, or participants can bring their own vessel to the ritual. The water ritual will occur several times during the year with different containers. This project is sponsored in part by the Emory College Center for Creativity and Arts.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events
Emory Event Topic: Arts
Department/Organization: Center for Creativity & Arts, Emory Dance Program

item.title: Film: Land of the Pharaohs
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Tuesday, October 18, 2011, 7:30 – 9:30 p.m.

A young Joan Collins plays the greedy second wife of the Old Kingdom pharaoh Khufu in "Land of the Pharaohs," directed by Howard Hawkes from a screenplay by William Faulkner. Shot on location in Egypt in 1955, the extravagant Hollywood epic used some 10,000 extras for scenes of the construction of the Khufu’s Great Pyramid. (106 min.) Dr. Matthew Bernstein, Chair of Emory’s Film Studies Department, will introduce this cult classic.

View the original trailer for the film by clicking on the link below.

Event type: Emory
Emory Event Topic: Arts
More info: www.tcm.com…

item.title: "Chinatown," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 208
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 19, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Roman Polanski; Paramount, 1974) (1.85:1, 140 min.) Produced by Robert Evans; written by Robert Towne; cinematography John Alonzo (& Stanley Cortez); music by Jerry Goldsmith; starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway, John Huston, Roman Polanski.

This Raymond Chandler-inspired "neo-noir" about civic corruption in 1930s Los Angeles is about as perfect a film as Hollywood has ever made. Under Polish émigré Roman Polanski's carefully modulated direction Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway and John Huston—himself the director of The Maltese Falcon, on many lists as the very first film noir—turned in some of the most memorable performances of their extraordinary careers. Jerry Goldsmith's haunting, evocative score—written and recorded in ten days—is ranked by the American Film Institute as one of the ten greatest scores of all time. Chinatown received a total of 11 Academy Award nominations, but only one win—for Robert Towne's original screenplay. It too is widely considered one of the best in Hollywood’s history. In 1991 the film was selected by the Library of Congress for inclusion on the National Film Registry. It looks to be Roman Polanski's last American film.

Water 2011-2012

item.title: Closing Reception: John W. Ford: House Not a Home
item.description:
Visual Arts Gallery
700 Peavine Creek Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 20, 2011, 5 – 8 p.m.

Exhibition dates: September 15 - October 22, 2011

Closing Reception: Thursday, October 20, 5–8 pm; Gallery Talk by John W. Ford, 6:30 pm
***************
John W. Ford is interested in objects, memory and space--both physical and metaphysical. He works in a wide variety of materials, from multimedia sculptures to installation to graphic arts.

“I am interested in the power of small objects and collections of small objects to catalyze interpretation and speculative meaning,” Ford explains.

Ford’s work has been shown in Ireland, Russia, Poland, Mexico, Canada and throughout the United States. He has been the recipient of numerous grants and awards including a Pollock Krasner Artist Grant, North Carolina Arts Council Artist Fellowship, Virginia A. Groot Foundation Grant, Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Grant, and an ArtsLink Project Grant.

item.title: Lecture: Egyptian Art of the Old Kingdom
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Thursday, October 20, 2011, 7:30 – 8:30 p.m.



The Old Kingdom saw the first great flowering of ancient Egyptian art. In a lecture titled "Egyptian Art of the Old Kingdom," Dr. Gay Robins, Samuel Candler Dobbs Professor of Art History at Emory, will explore the many achievements of Egyptian artists during the period and explain the functions of the monuments commissioned by the king and his elite officials that led to the development of this unique visual culture.

Event type: Emory
Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: "FLOW," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Friday, October 21, 2011, 7 p.m.

Irena Salina builds a case against the growing privatization of the world’s dwindling fresh water supply with an unflinching focus on politics, pollution, human rights, and the emergence of a domineering world water cartel in this award-winning documentary. The screening will be introduced by Matthew Bernstein, Chair, Film and Media Studies and Christine Moe, Director of the Center for Global Safe Water, and then followed by a question and answer discussion.

item.title: "Piano in a Factory," film screening
item.description:
Goodrich C. White Hall
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Saturday, October 22, 2011, 4 – 5:45 p.m.

Piano In A Factory (China, 2010, 100 min)
Director: Meng Zheng
In Mandarin with English subtitles

When Chen's estranged wife reappears asking for a divorce and custody of their daughter, the musician girl decides she will live with whoever can provide her with a piano. Chen's struggle thus begins. When efforts to borrow money and even steal a piano fail, Chen concocts a preposterous plan - he'll make a piano from scratch! He persuades a bunch of reluctant, but loyal, misfit friends to help him forge the instrument in a derelict factory from a heap of scrap steel. Though crude in design and tune, the factory piano awaits its first and final performance from his little girl.

item.title: FULL-Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum, Tate Room
Sunday, October 23, 2011, 2 – 4 p.m.

FULL-Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
In addition to mummifying the bodies of human beings, the Ancient Egyptians also mummified animals, including birds, crocodiles, cats, and fish. In the first session of this two-part workshop children will visit the galleries to examine animal and human mummies. Then they will re-create natron, the ancient salt used by the Egyptians in the mummification process to dehydrate the body, and seal their fish in the mixture. In the second session on November 6th, they will anoint the mummified body with scented oils and practice the art of wrapping the mummy with strips of fine linen. Ages 8-12. $12 for Museum members; $15 for non-members. Pre-registration is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Event type: Emory
Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Lecture & Discussion: The Art of Insight and Communing with the Unseen
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Sunday, October 23, 2011, 2 – 4:30 p.m.

In conjunction with the exhibition, "Divine Intervention: African Art and Religion," Mary (Polly) Nooter Roberts, Professor in UCLA’s Department of World Arts and Cultures, and Brendan Ozawa-de Silva, Associate Director of the Drepung Loseling Monastery in Atlanta, will discuss divination among the Luba in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and in Tibetan Buddhism.

In a lecture titled, "The Art of Insight: Mediating Spirit and Human Realms in Central African Divination," Dr. Roberts will discuss the objects and practices through which Luba diviners “see” problems and find solutions to life’s most challenging circumstances.

In a lecture titled, "Communing with the Unseen: The Role of Oracles and Divination in Tibetan Politics, Medicine, and Spirituality," Dr. Ozawa-de Silva will explain the manner of consulting an oracle or diviner, the role of the mediums and their practices, the use of subsequent rituals based on received advice, and the broader context of unseen beings in Tibetan Buddhism.

This program is being held in memory of Dr. Ivan Karp, beloved colleague, mentor, and friend.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events
Emory Event Topic: Arts, International, Lectures & Meetings, Religion & Ethics
Building/Room: Carlos Museum
Cost: Free

Contact Email: priyanka.sinha@emory.edu
More info: carlos.emory.edu

item.description:

1700 North Decatur Road

item.title: Discussion/Book-signing: Mark Auslander
item.description:
Jones Room, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Monday, October 24, 2011, 4 – 6 p.m.



Auslander is the author of “The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family,” a book about Catherine “Miss Kitty” Boyd and Methodist Bishop James Osgood Andrew, the first president of Emory’s board of trustees. Discussion will include the role of the Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library (MARBL) in his research, his successful efforts to track down Miss Kitty’s descendants, the effects of his research and published work on the Emory and Oxford College communities, and medical discoveries made from treating enslaved people.

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, October 24, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Robert Graves’ two novels, "I Claudius" and "Claudius the God" paint a compelling portrait of Rome’s first imperial dynasty, the Julio-Claudians. Meticulously based on ancient authors such as Tacitus and Suetonius, the novels reveal Graves’ expert training in Classics at Oxford. But how accurate is Graves’s depiction? Dr. Eric Varner, Associate Professor of Art History and Classics, will lead readers in an investigation not just of the novels themselves, but of what art historical and archaeological evidence might also reveal about the hidden lives of Rome’s First Family. Fee, which includes the cost of both books: $50 for Museum members; $75 for non-members.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

item.description:
Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
1700 North Decatur Road

Join us for the STIPE Gallery opening of a new exhibit from student Charlotte Watts. "Dating is Dead, Let's F*ck" explores sexuality and dating in the age of hooking up. Watts speaks with Julia Kjelgaard, chair of the Visual Arts Department, about her research, creating these striking new works, and her philosophy about the hook-up culture.

item.title: Free Poetry Reading with D.A. Powell
item.description:
Jones Room, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Wednesday, October 26, 2011, 6 – 7:30 p.m.

Award-winning poet D.A. Powell will read and sign books Wednesday, Oct. 26 at 6 p.m. in the Jones Room at the Woodruff Library on the Emory University campus.

Born in Albany, Georgia, Powell writes poetry with subjects ranging from movies, music, art, and other aspects of modern culture to the AIDS epidemic. Powell's first three collections of poetry, "Tea," "Lunch," and "Cocktails," are viewed as a trilogy on the AIDS epidemic. His fourth book, "Chronic," received the Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award and was nominated for a National Book Critics Circle Award. His fifth book is due out in February 2012.

Books and a limited-edition broadside will be available for sale and signing. Light refreshments will be served after the reading.

Woodruff Library is located at 540 Asbury Circle on the Emory campus in Atlanta, 30322. Parking is available in the Fishburne Deck; visit bit.ly… for directions.

item.title: "The Blue Dahlia," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 26, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(George Marshall; Paramount, 1946) (1.37:1, 96 min.) Produced by John Houseman; written by Raymond Chandler; cinematography by Lionel Lindon; starring Alan Ladd, Veronica Lake, William Bendix.

Though less remembered today than Bogart and Mitchum, Alan Ladd was not only one of the earliest of noir's tough-guy anti-heroes but arguably the hardest of them all. It was his performance as an ice-cold hit man in 1942’s adaptation of Graham Greene's This Gun For Hire that turned Ladd into a star. From there Paramount moved him and his similarly cool co-star Veronica Lake on to other hardboiled writers like Dashiell Hammett (The Glass Key, 1942) and with this film, Raymond Chandler. The Blue Dahlia, Ladd's first film after his army discharge, was also Chandler’s first attempt at an original screenplay. Furious with director Marshall for shooting his own dialogue while Chandler was still trying to finish the screenplay, Chandler also fought with the Navy who felt similarly entitled to re-write his script because it featured a discharged vet. Not surprisingly Chandler spent his working hours with an open bottle next to the typewriter, something that didn't prevent the completed script from receiving an Academy Award nomination.

item.title: Workshop for Teachers: Sacred Carving of the Ancient Egyptians
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room and Galleries
Thursday, October 27, 2011, 5 – 7 p.m.

In a workshop titled Sacred Carving of the Ancient Egyptians, Michele Marlar, Assistant Professor in the Visual Arts Program at Morehouse College, will lead teachers on an exploration of the history and development of Egyptian hieroglyphs and some of the major texts that preserve the ancient Egyptian belief system. Dr. Marlar will look at hieroglyphic writing in the Museum’s Egyptian Galleries and in the exhibition Life and Death in the Pyramid Age: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy.
Contact Julie Green to register, jgree09@emory.edu.
Fee: $7 for Museum members and $10 for non-members.

item.title: "Early Italian Painters and the Secret Life of Stones," Art History Endowed Lecture
item.description:
Reception Hall, Michael C. Carlos Museum
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 27, 2011, 5:30 p.m.

Anne Dunlop, Associate Professor, History of Art at Tulane University, gives the lecture "Early Italian Painters and the Secret Life of Stones." Sponsored by the Art History Endowed Lectureship, the Michael C. Carlos Museum, and the Lila Acheson Wallace-Reader's Digest Lecture Program.

Early Italian paintings were made with gold from Africa and silvers and tins from northern and central Europe, with lapis from central Asia, and local earths and stones. This talk looks at the associations that these materials brought with them, and how the properties of pigments gave meaning to the paintings they were used to create.

Anne Dunlop is Associate Chair for Art History in the Newcomb Art Department of Tulane University. She works on the painting and culture of fourteenth- and fifteenth-century Italy. She is the author of "Painted Palaces: the Rise of Secular Art in Early Renaissance Italy" (Penn State Press, 2009), and co-editor of "Art and the Augustinian Order in Early Renaissance Italy" (Ashgate, 2007).

item.title: ECHOLILIA, A Conversation with Timothy Archibald
item.description:
Center for Ethics
1531 Dickey Drive
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 27, 2011, 6 – 8 p.m.

ECHOLILIA: The Spectrum of Childhood and the Documentation of a Relationship—Photographs by Father and Son

A Conversation with Timothy Archibald
Moderated by Rosemarie Garland-Thomson

Dr. Garland-Thomson will lead a discussion with Timothy about ECHOLILIA, paying special attention to the representation of disability, the collaborative role of father and son, the power of looking, and the role this project has played not only in Eli’s life and development but also in the Archibald family as a whole.

Timothy Archibald, celebrated San Francisco based commercial photographer, struggled to connect with his five-year old firstborn, Eli—the tension in their home was palpable—until Timothy started looking at his son through his camera. Together, the two orchestrated a portrait series that depicts dreamy, intimate images not only of Eli but of childhood itself, riddled as it is with mystery and fantasy. In doing so, Archibald documents the burgeoning of a newly charted relationship with his son. Through their creative collaboration, empowerment came to both Timothy and Eli. Timothy found a way to dial-in to Eli’s different channel, thereby breaching the previously challenging obstacle posed by his son’s autistic proclivities. And Eli found a powerful mirror both of his robust, imaginative childhood and his renewed bond with his dad.

Made possible by the generous support of the School of Medicine, Center for Ethics, Autism Center, Graduate Student Government Association, Visual Scholarship Initiative, Visual Arts Department, Office of the Provost, Hightower Fund, and Race & Difference Initiative of Emory University, as well as Atlanta Celebrates Photography and the Marcus Autism Center.

item.title: Mummies and Milkshakes
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum, Reception Hall
Friday, October 28, 2011, 6:30 – 8:30 p.m.

The Carlos Museum and Jake’s Ice Cream present the seventh annual Mummies and Milkshakes. Visit animal and human mummies in the Egyptian galleries and the oldest true Egyptian mummy in the Western Hemisphere in the exhibition Life and Death in the Pyramid Age: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy. Choose your favorite Jake’s Ice Cream flavor for a milkshake, and watch funny vintage mummy cartoons and the hilarious Three Stooges short, We Want Our Mummy, followed by Abbot and Costello Meet the Mummy.

Milkshakes for sale beginning at 6:30 pm, cartoons at 7 pm, film begins at 7:45 pm. Free to Museum members; $5 for non-members. Costumes encouraged! Milkshakes sold separately. Galleries open from 6 to 9:30 pm. RSVP required by Wednesday, October 27 by calling 404.727.0519.

Timothy Archibald, celebrated San Francisco based commercial photographer, struggled to connect with his five-year old firstborn, Eli—the tension in their home was palpable—until Timothy started looking at his son through his camera. Together, the two orchestrated a portrait series that depicts dreamy, intimate images not only of Eli but of childhood itself, riddled as it is with mystery and fantasy. In doing so, Archibald documents the burgeoning of a newly charted relationship with his son. Through their creative collaboration, empowerment came to both Timothy and Eli. Timothy found a way to dial-in to Eli’s different channel, thereby breaching the previously challenging obstacle posed by his son’s autistic proclivities. And Eli found a powerful mirror both of his robust, imaginative childhood and his renewed bond with his dad.

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, October 31, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Robert Graves’ two novels, "I Claudius" and "Claudius the God" paint a compelling portrait of Rome’s first imperial dynasty, the Julio-Claudians. Meticulously based on ancient authors such as Tacitus and Suetonius, the novels reveal Graves’ expert training in Classics at Oxford. But how accurate is Graves’s depiction? Dr. Eric Varner, Associate Professor of Art History and Classics, will lead readers in an investigation not just of the novels themselves, but of what art historical and archaeological evidence might also reveal about the hidden lives of Rome’s First Family. Fee, which includes the cost of both books: $50 for Museum members; $75 for non-members.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

An intimate movement series uncovering the architecture, process, and findings of faculty choreography at Emory University.

This series will be an ongoing sharing of various stages of the choreographic process. Choreographers may present after performances, sharing their findings and illuminations; or while they are living the dynamic, chaotic process of crafting and discovering; or during the initial, impulsive cultivation of concepts, thoughts, images, and movement.

item.title: "Crossfire," film screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, November 2, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Edward Dmytryk; RKO, 1947) (1.37:1, 86 min.) Produced by Adrian Scott & Dore Schary; cinematography by J. Roy Hunt; starring Robert Young, Robert Mitchum, Robert Ryan and Gloria Grahame. Print courtesy of the Academy Film Archive.

Crossfire was the fourth and last film from the team of Dmytryk and Scott, who first collaborated on the 1944 noir classic, Murder, My Sweet. Drawn from future director (In Cold Blood) Richard Brooks' novel The Brick Foxhole about a psychotic soldier who murders a homosexual, the Production Code’s prohibition against any reference to "sexual perversion" required that the murder’s motivation be changed. Scott and company settled on anti-Semitism. Even so, Code enforcer Joseph Breen warned the filmmakers against any "suggestion of a 'pansy' characterization." Four months after Crossfire’s release, Communists Dmytryk, Scott and eight other screenwriters dubbed "the Hollywood Ten" refused to testify before the House UnAmerican Activities Committee about Communism in Hollywood. Contempt citations were immediately issued and within 24 hours all were blacklisted from further work in the industry. Three months later, Crossfire garnered four major Academy Award nominations. Ultimately beat out for Best Picture by the similarly-themed Gentleman’s Agreement, it still took home the Best Social Film at Cannes. Two years later Dmytryk, Scott and the rest of the 'ten' went to jail.

item.title: “Art, Artists, & Archives: A Conversation with Hazel Biggers & Amalia K. Amaki”
item.description:
Jones Room, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Thursday, November 3, 2011, 4 – 5:30 p.m.

The Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library (MARBL) at Emory University recently acquired two major collections: the papers of artist John Biggers and collector Paul R. Jones. The conversation, moderated by Emory Professor Emeritus Richard A. Long, will address the importance of preserving papers related to artists and art history. Co-sponsored by MARBL, ILA and the departments of Art History and African American Studies.

item.title: FULL-Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room
Sunday, November 6, 2011, 2 – 4 p.m.

FULL-Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
This is the second part of a two part workshop.
In addition to mummifying humans, the ancient Egyptians also mummified animals including birds, crocodiles, cats, and fish. In this two-part workshop, children will visit the galleries to examine animal and human mummies. Then they will "mummify" a fish. They will re-create natron, the ancient salt used by the Egyptians to dehydrate the body, and seal their fish in the mixture. In the second session on October 2nd, they will anoint the mummified body with scented oils and practice the art of wrapping the mummy with strips of linen. Ages 8-12. $12 for Museum members; $15 for non-members. Pre-registration is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Event type: Emory
Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: African Dance for Health and Well-Being
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Monday, November 7, 2011, 5 – 6:30 p.m.

For six Monday afternoons, the Carlos Museum invites you to dance to the rhythms of live African drums with Giwayen Mata. Move to the direction of Omelika Kuumba and members of this three-time winner of Creative Loafing's Choice Award for Top Traditional/World Music and Dance group. Giwayen Mata will warm you up, work you out and cool you down with movements, rhythms, and songs as well as explain the cultural contexts for each dance. You are guaranteed to experience your muscles thoroughly and leave each session feeling revived and rejuvenated.
Fee: $60 for Museum members, $80 for non-members

item.title: Natasha Trethewey, The Phillis Wheatley Reading
item.description:
Jones Room, 311 Woodruff Library
540 Asbury Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Monday, November 7, 2011, 6:30 p.m.

Poet. Natasha Trethewey is the author of three collections of poetry: "Domestic Work," "Bellocq's Ophelia," and "Native Guard," for which she was awarded the 2007 Pulitzer Prize. She is also the author of a book of creative non-fiction, "Beyond Katrina: A Meditation on the Mississippi Gulf Coast." Her fourth collection of poetry, Thrall, is forthcoming in Fall 2012. She is the recipient of fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Bunting Fellowship Program of the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University, and the National Endowment for the Arts. Trethewey is also the recipient of the 2008 Mississippi Governor's Award for Excellence in the Arts and was named the 2008 Georgia Woman of the Year. In 2009 she was inducted into the Fellowship of Southern Writers and in 2011 she was inducted into the Georgia Writers Hall of Fame. Booksigning to follow. Co-sponsored by the Department of African American Studies.

item.title: Workshop: Learning to See, Learning to Draw
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room and Galleries
Thursday, November 10, 2011, 5 – 6:30 p.m.

Drawing in museums is a time-honored tradition. Led by veteran art teacher Cathy Amos, teachers will receive resource materials and will spend time in the galleries practice a variety of drawing methods including drawing to record and drawing to analyze. Teachers will receive step-by-step instructions for using drawing as an aid and to supplement note taking.
Contact Julie Green to register, jgree09@emory.edu.
Fee: $7 for Museum members and $10 for non-members.

item.title: Artful Stories: Aesop's Fables
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Greek and Roman Galleries
Saturday, November 12, 2011, 10 a.m. – 12 p.m.

Originating in Greece, the stories attributed to Aesop have been told as a way to entertain and teach useful lessons for more than 2500 years. Some stories are well known, like the Tortoise and the Hare and the Wind and the Sun, while many others like the Vain Jackdaw or the Venus and the Cat are not so familiar. Come hear a selection of Aesop's Fables where animals behave like humans, amid the art of Ancient Greece. After the story, we will search for animals in the collections and create an image on a "black-figure vase" in paper. For ages 3 to 5 years and accompanying adults. These programs are free but a reservation is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

item.title: The Somewhere Summit: Connecting the Local to the Global in Atlanta Art
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall, Third Floor
Saturday, November 12, 2011, 10 a.m. – 3 p.m.

The Somewhere Summit is an open Arts dialogue designed for Atlanta-based artists, scholars, arts administrators and other cultural workers interested in gaining a deeper understanding of how Atlanta artists are positioned within a global contemporary art framework. Prompted by Atlanta Art Now’s 2011 publication, Noplaceness: Art in a Post-Urban Landscape, The Somewhere Summit will specifically discuss two related questions: How are artists redefining the idea of place and locality as these concepts shift in an era of rapid geographic, demographic and technological changes, and what does that mean for how Atlanta artists relate to the rest of the world?

Schedule At-A-Glance

10:00 am – 10:30 am Registration & Book Signing

10:30 am – 11:30 pm Book Discussion with Authors --moderated by Louis Corrigan

11:30 pm – 11:45 pm Break

11:45 pm – 12:45 pm Panel I: Place – “Does Local Art Matter in a Global Age?”

Moderated by Cinque Hicks. Featured panelists include: Anne Collins-Smith, Spelman College Museum of Fine Art; Diana McClintock, Professor of Art History at Kennesaw State University, Contributor & Art Critic for Art Papers; Qi Wang, Assistant Professor at Georgia Tech.

12:45 pm – 1:45 pm Lunch Break

1:45 pm – 2:45 pm Panel II: Artists in Practice -- What Are the Challenges and Opportunities for Making Art in Atlanta’s Public Space?

Moderated by Benjamin Flowers, Ph.D and Associate Professor at Georgia Institute of Technology. Featured panelists include: Monica Campana, Co-founder of Living Walls; Anne Dennington, Executive Director of Flux Projects; Sarah Emerson, Professor of Art at Emory University and featured artist in Noplaceness; and Michael Simanga, Director of Fulton Country Arts Council.

3:00 pm End of Program

Special Thanks
The Somewhere Summit is organized by Atlanta Art Now, with support from ArtsCriticATL, Black Art in America, and Burnaway.

ABOUT
Published by Possible Futures, Inc., Atlanta Art Now is a biennial publication that emerged from the increasing need for a highly visible platform for critical writing about Atlanta visual artists. The 2011 edition, Noplaceness, examines contemporary artists whose work examines issues of place and space as these concepts shift in the context of globalization. The Somewhere Summit will extend the critical impact and mission of Atlanta Art Now by providing a deeper context for the issues raised in the book.

Atlanta Art Now’s 2011 volume, “Noplaceness: Art in a Post-Urban Landscape,” is written by Atlanta based writers Jerry Cullum, Catherine Fox and Cinqué Hicks and features a foreword by Valerie Cassel Oliver, Senior Curator of the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston. The book explores work by Atlanta artists dealing with the shifting physical and psychological spaces encountered in the new global era while probing artists’ reactions to evolving ideas of modern ideas of place. Organized into thematic chapters, NOPLACENESS will also feature several color plates of the artwork discussed.

item.title: Workshop: The Art of the Print in Social Commentary
item.description:
Tate Room
Sunday, November 13, 2011, 2 – 5 p.m.

The Harlot's Progress is a series of engravings by British artist William Hogarth that tells the story of Moll Hackabout, a fictional young woman who arrives in London seeking employment, but is lured into a life of dissolution. Through these works, Hogarth uses satire to bring the darker side of the city to light in a humorous yet poignant way, and reveals a cast of characters identifiable as well known eighteenth century Londoners. By using a sequence of images to tell the story, Hogarth paved the way for future artists and photojournalists to address injustice through serial graphics. Participants will view the exhibition and other works dealing with social justice, then they will work with a printmaker to develop a series of images addressing social justice issues important to them. Finally, they will make an etching of their images. Due to the mature themes of these artworks, this workshop is for ages 14 and up.
Fee: $12 for Museum members, $15 for non-members. Please RSVP to Nina West at 404-727-0519.

Event type: Seminars / Workshops

item.title: African Dance for Health and Well-Being
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Monday, November 14, 2011, 5 – 6:30 p.m.

For six Monday afternoons, the Carlos Museum invites you to dance to the rhythms of live African drums with Giwayen Mata. Move to the direction of Omelika Kuumba and members of this three-time winner of Creative Loafing's Choice Award for Top Traditional/World Music and Dance group. Giwayen Mata will warm you up, work you out and cool you down with movements, rhythms, and songs as well as explain the cultural contexts for each dance. You are guaranteed to experience your muscles thoroughly and leave each session feeling revived and rejuvenated.
Fee: $60 for Museum members, $80 for non-members

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, November 14, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Robert Graves’ two novels, "I Claudius" and "Claudius the God" paint a compelling portrait of Rome’s first imperial dynasty, the Julio-Claudians. Meticulously based on ancient authors such as Tacitus and Suetonius, the novels reveal Graves’ expert training in Classics at Oxford. But how accurate is Graves’s depiction? Dr. Eric Varner, Associate Professor of Art History and Classics, will lead readers in an investigation not just of the novels themselves, but of what art historical and archaeological evidence might also reveal about the hidden lives of Rome’s First Family. Fee, which includes the cost of both books: $50 for Museum members; $75 for non-members.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events

item.description:

item.title: "Devil in a Blue Dress," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, November 16, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Carl Franklin Columbia-TriStar, 1995) (1.85:1, 102 min.) Written by Franklin from a book by Walter Mosley; cinematography by Tak Fujimoto; music by Elmer Bernstein; starring Denzel Washington, Tom Sizemore, Jennifer Beals, Don Cheadle.

Tired of waiting for a call to direct something with an African-American theme, actor-director Carl Franklin sat down and wrote his own screenplay from the first of Walter Mosley's novels featuring black private detective Easy Rollins. Set in post-war Watts, the film offered, in the words of one reviewer, 'another shade of noir.' As Easy, Denzel Washington turns in a typically smooth portrayal, in the laid back tradition of Robert Mitchum. But the film's standout performance is undoubtedly Don Cheadle as Easy's hair-trigger psychotic friend "Mouse." Their relationship alone sets the film apart from its earlier white models. Top-drawer cinematography of Tak Fujimoto and a standout soundtrack, rich in forties jazz, R&B and jump blues, all nicely help evoke the atmosphere of the now lost Central Ave. scene of late forties Los Angeles.

Event type: Arts and Cultural Events
Emory Event Topic: Arts
Department/Organization: Film Studies
Series: Emory Cinematheque Series
Event Open To: All
Venue: Room 205

Cost: Free

item.title: Lecture: Ancient Celebrities, Eternal Real Estate: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy and excavations at Abydos, Egypt
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Thursday, November 17, 2011, 7:30 – 8:30 p.m.

Location, location, location. In ancient Egypt, the “where” of your tomb was just as important as the “what” — its decoration and contents — especially for wealthy and politically prominent people. In a lecture titled "Ancient Celebrities, Eternal Real Estate: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy and excavations at Abydos, Egypt," Dr. Janet Richards, Director of the University of Michigan excavations in the Abydos Middle Cemetery, sheds new light not only on the character of the exclusive burial enclave that was home to Emory’s Old Kingdom mummy, but also on the lives and afterlives of his famous neighbors, and the very nature of ancient celebrity.

Event type: Emory
Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Jane Austen's Persuasion
item.description:
Mary Gray Munroe Theater
3rd Floor of the Dobbs University Center
605 Asbury Circle
Atlanta, Georgia 30322
Saturday, November 19, 2011, 7 p.m.

Young and privileged Anne was forced by her family to reject her true love, Frederick, because of his inadequate social standing. Now, an almost-spinster at age 27, Anne suddenly re-encounters Frederick, who is now wealthy and distinguished but also too hurt to forgive Anne for her rejection of him years ago.

Performances:
Nov. 10-12, 7 p.m.
Nov. 16-19, 7 p.m.
Nov. 13 and Nov. 20, 2 p.m.

Purchase tickets online or call 404-727-5050

item.title: Without Which Nothing, Reading
item.description:
Schwartz Center for Performing Arts, Theater Lab
1700 N. Decatur Rd.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Saturday, November 19, 2011, 7 – 8 p.m.

Water is central to the myths and rituals of most religions. Water is essential for life. Water is running out. Without Which Nothing interweaves stories surrounding the complex questions, the mystery, the sanctity, and urgent global problem of water. This play is in development by Out of Hand Theater and the Playwriting Center of Theater Emory.
